Mr. Taylor, it appears that the Soviet musical officials
feel that music should have a mass appeal. I wonder
whether you feel that if music has to cater to what
you might call a mass intelligibility, does that
seriously interfere with the composer*s art?
I think it very seriously and very emphatically does
interfere because what it boils down to is that he must
write*only such music as will have immediate acceptance
by a musically illiterate audience. Well, thatâ€™s true
enough that music can be good and still have immediate
acceptance, but it doesn't necessarily mean that that's
the only kind of music, or that it will eventually be
accepted. I think that the Soviets leave no margin for
any growth in appreciation of music. If everything must
be a tune rather than a theme, music will remain static.
It allows no room for experimentO'eithor in content or
in form.
I am wondering very much whether people really like
music all alike all the time. Don't you think that the
person who decides what people like usually think^ they
only like one thing , whereas people really like a very
wide variety of things. I wonder then what is music
which is of the people, and what is music which could

Well, I must say that as I listen to a great deal of
